citation.article-title: Pasteurella skyensis sp. nov., isolated from Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar L.).
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pasteurella skyensis sp. nov.
Pasteurella skyensis (skye.en'sis. N.L. fem. adj. skyensis pertaining to Skye, the island in Scotland, UK, where the first two isolates of this species were isolated)
Cells are pleomorphic, non-motile, Gram-negative rods that are facultatively anaerobic.
Colonies on TSSBA incubated in air for 48 h at 22 °C are circular, entire, low, convex, smooth, grey and 0.5 mm in diameter.
The addition of salt (1.5%, w/v) and blood to trypticase soy agar or Columbia agar is required for growth.
X and V factors do not permit growth on blood-free media.
Growth occurs at 14-32 °C but not at 37 °C.
Catalase-negative and weakly positive for oxidase activity.

Acid is produced from glucose, lactose, maltose, mannose, mannitol and trehalose, but not from adonitol, arbutin, dulcitol, galactose, inositol, inulin, melibiose, raffinose, rhamnose, salicin, sucrose, sorbitol or xylose.
Strains produce ornithine decarboxylase and lysine decarboxylase but not arginine dihydrolase.
Alkaline phosphatase and acid phosphatase are produced.
The G­C content of the DNA of the four isolates is 39-41%, as determined by the thermal method.
The description of the type strain corresponds to that of the species, and the G­C content of the DNA is 41 mol%.
